Posts.Content: CassDugan wrote: I've been looking through Lumpectomy Lounge (http://community.breastcancer.org/topic_post?forum_id=91&id=800729&page=1) and Shopping/packing/to-do list for surgery + recovery....(http://community.breastcancer.org/topic_post?forum_id=91&id=699896&page=1) but haven't found quite what I'm looking for. I am scheduled for a lumpectomy later this month.  I too am a compulsive planner and want to know more about the recovery process.  The three things I've understood this far are:  healing from a lumpectomy is much different than a mastectomy - those tips don't really apply, have some high-impact sports bras on hand (would front opening be better than pull-over?), have ice packs or other means applying cold on hand.  Yet, I cannot help but feel I could be better prepared. What I'm wondering is, for those of you who have been through a lumpectomy, what are the most important couple of tips you could give someone about to go through it?   What is the one thing you wish you had known ahead of your surgery?   What did you find most helpful during your recovery?  Or even during your ride home from surgery? Thanks in advance!! edit:  to remove nonfunctional html tags - not sure how to create a hyperlink in the bb software & the buttons to do so are inactive Surgery 5/17/2013 Lumpectomy: Left Surgery 6/14/2013 Lymph node removal: Left, Sentinel Radiation Therapy 7/8/2013 Breast, Lymph nodes Hormonal Therapy 9/15/2013 Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy: Your tips for preparation & recovery? CassDugan carol57

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2013 02:04PM CassDugan wrote: Apologies for posting and disappearing. I'm glad some of you have found this helpful! My 5/17 surgery that this thread prompted was not a lumpectomy but a partial mastectomy. Apparently, the difference is the amount of tissue resected. I had a second surgery in mid-June (SLNB) and have now been off narcotics long enough that I feel coherent again. What I learned from people's posts: Extra big button up shirts are essential, as are front opening sports bras and multiple ice packs. I lived in these for weeks after surgery. A larger fitting bra is also helpful. I got sent home in a surgical bra which fit easily over a sports bra. It helped immensely in holding ice packs in place. The SLNB came 3 weeks after the partial mx. Bras were trickier since they were closer to or even crossed over the incision. What I learned and would like to pass along: Bras with seamless areas over the breast are a must. I received two Amoena bras from the hospital. Super-comfy, but the seam and puckering from the front gathering were problematic. I developed some red splotches that went away a few days after I stopped wearing them. The seams are good for judging swelling, though. If you have someone who is helping you to dress, give clear instructions before the process starts, including what to do if it goes badly. My partner was helping me to manage pullover sports bras and some camis with built in sports bras. We had a few incidents dissolve into frustration and tears because he didn't know how to manage them and I was stuck, partway in, in an uncomfortable position, desperately trying to hold the rolled up tight part off and away from the parts of me that hurt.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy: Your tips for preparation & recovery? CassDugan carol57

Posts.Title: Lumpectomy: Your tips for preparation & recovery? CassDugan carol57

Posts.Content: May 1, 2013 07:18AM CassDugan wrote: Thanks for all your input!  Surgery's been moved up to 5/17 - 4 days after my last final, so not much time to prepare... Sounds like it's definitely worthwhile to get a couple of front-opening high-impact sports bras.  As a runner, I have many sports bras, but being on the small side, none that open in front. As a whole-foodsy vegan, constipation is a non-issue, but that's a great tip (pain meds & constipation) and one I've heard before. I cook a lot & have a freezer filled with leftovers, so meals are covered even though it's depleted over the semester.  I made sure to make bread last weekend since I won't know when I'll be up to kneading again - my kneading arm & lumpectomy breast are on the same side.  Excellent tip for people who don't tend to keep food on hand. Exercise:  as an athletic person, my problem will be resting rather than getting moving.  Great link to exercises ruthbru - I'll try to use some of those until I can get back to my regular routines. Big button up shirt for the ride home.  Check.  I'll raid my partner's closet since he's got some ratty old shirts.  I was thinking an oversized T, but this makes more sense. Keep the tips coming!
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy: Your tips for preparation & recovery? CassDugan carol57

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2013 02:25PM CassDugan wrote: That's an important part I missed. I paid careful attention to the warnings about not lifting or jostling during the first couple of weeks, but I did so slow and careful ROM exercises. Although there were times I found bearing weight to be uncomfortable, at no point did I find my range of motion limited very much. In the past several days I am picking back up with running and my usual light upper body weights routine and having no trouble with either. I'm careful to start conservatively, knowing I can work back up to what I was doing. The upper body stretches pull, but in a good way. I had feeling almost all the way back. My partial mastectomy removed a cone of tissue pretty much central in the breast. The incision forms an approximately 4" scar across my breast. If you picture the nipple as the center of a clock, and straight up as noon, my scar centers on the center and runs 3 to 9. Resection of the aerolar complex is a requirement with Paget's. I had some numbness early on. My partner and I have been doing blind tests where he touches various spots in different way while I try to detect where and how he is touching without looking. My numb area was starting to experience ticklish feelings about a week ago. It again seems numb. The SLNB caused no numbness and continues to have feeling.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy: Your tips for preparation & recovery? CassDugan carol57

Posts.Content: CassDugan wrote: When considering a mastectomy or lumpectomy, is it reasonable to ask the surgeon to see pictures of some of their patients?  Will they generally provide things like that? ETA:  That is, pictures of how the surgical site appears after healing. Sophia, all I can say is that the RO showed me the plan and that it did not include my throat. The RO said that if my lymph were also being treated (SLNB negative, so it isn't), then the field would include my throat. It's hard to know what to believe. Given the timing and the unusualness of the symptoms for me, it seems like it would have to be related. How about pain? I couldn't sleep for it Thursday night. I'm up again tonight, Friday, after only a couple of hours.

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2013 10:51PM CassDugan wrote: Oh my gosh did the fatigue ever hit me on the way home today. I thought of pulling over at the rest stop for a nap on my drive home but we had a realtor coming tonight to discuss selling my house. I managed some housework but I was so freaking tired I kept sitting and crying a little. One day and then two more weeks. Some discomfort issues but my skin is still intact, if noticeably pink. I'm taking it one day at a time. Tomorrow, two days off, and then two more weeks, the latter part of which is coning down. I am caught between: yay only 11 more treatments; and omg really I have to do 11 more? Sorry - tired and babbling.

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2013 10:31PM CassDugan wrote: I started rads yesterday and am scheduled for 6 weeks, until mid-August. I had a partial mx in mid-May and SLNB (negative) in mid june. I too am doing a breath hold technique, but with nothing like the snorkel or glasses mentioned up thread. After I got home today, I changed and noticed that the treated breast felt noticeably warmer than the other breast. This was about 2 hours after treatment. I reviewed the handouts and could not find this listed among the SE's. I'm not worried but am wondering if anyone else has noticed this?
Posts.Title: Summer 2013 Rads Wildlyshel sandiesau

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2013 12:19AM CassDugan wrote: 10/30 today, 4 weeks to go. I noticed toward the end of both last week and this week that I'm feeling a sort of a lump in my throat that I've seen other women mention. It's a great appetite suppressant, feeling like there something caught partway through swallowing. It's on the list to ask my RO about next week. Last week, the feeling was gone by Sunday midday. This week it was back Wednesday night. I almost never have digestive issues and my diet is about the same so I'm tending to think it's rads related. Any recommendations for things that have worked for other women? I've tried taking some OTC remedies for digestive troubles like gas or heartburn but no luck. I tried cough medicine too.
Posts.Title: Summer 2013 Rads Wildlyshel sandiesau

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2013 03:47PM CassDugan wrote: Halfway done today: 15 of 30. My skin is pinking up a bit but is otherwise in good shape. Though the fields do not include my esophagus at all, I have a persistent lump in my throat as well as frequent heartburn which I'd never experienced before in my life. My RO says it cannot be related but I'm skeptical, especially since I can google and find many medical sites that state that it can be an SE of whole breast radiation. I am fatigued, but whether it's the rads, the lack of sleep (those shooting pains aren't helpful), my long commute, stress, or any combination of the preceding, who knows. But, overall, doing pretty well I think.
Posts.Title: Summer 2013 Rads Wildlyshel sandiesau

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2013 04:59AM CassDugan wrote: Yes, the RO did give me a 'scrip for oxycodone which worked well for me following each of the surgeries. As of 2 days ago, I also decided to max out on ibuprophen too. Even if it doesn't seem to be having much of an analgesic affect, it should help with the inflammation. The treated breast has been swelling some which I'd guess must be contributing to the pain. For me, I haven't had skin pain at all. I ache in one spot, much like the ache after a too strenuous workout. That's not too bad. The oxy helps less with the rest of it. I'm also having some shooting pains inside the remains of the breast, mostly right in the middle. Less frequently I'm having some worse pain - sharp, sudden, and over quickly - it's like a white hot wire getting pulled through. Overall, I'm not in a lot of pain, but it wears you down, y'know? During the day I can distract myself pretty easily. Plus, it seems to get worse as the day wears on. Ive been taking the oxy only at night but there are still nights I can't sleep because I just can't get comfortable or because the shooting pains just won't quit. Only three more weeks! For anyone else who's experienced the feeling of a lump in the throat - any tips? The RO recommended Prilosec which hasn't helped at all. I'll give it a few more days to be sure. Thanks all!
Posts.Title: Summer 2013 Rads Wildlyshel sandiesau

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2013 04:33AM CassDugan wrote: I hadn't explored the profile beyond articles. Thank you! Prilosec - tomorrow makes a week. If no help, the rest goes in the trash. Mylanta - thanks for the tip, I'll try that. I haven't had nausea but have had lots of heart burn and gas. I almost never have digestive issues. It's not supposed to be rads-related, but I wonder just the same. Could be stress related too, long drive in. Today was 16/30. My skin has been pinking up but after today is much pinker. It otherwise looks ok. I've been using Aloe Life Skin Gel 2-3 times a day. I agree that our skin's needs can be different and what the RO recommends can be different.

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2013 07:58PM CassDugan wrote: Lynn13ka - many thanks, subscribed to that thread. Like you, I sailed through rads. Some fatigue and feeling a lump in my throat, but that was it. I'd forgotten all about the throat lump until posting again recently. Two weeks later, the throat lump is gone, I have less pain, but the outer layers of skin are finally shedding. I'm not sure if the fatigue is worse, better, or still the same. I have a lot going on (getting my house ready to list, school starting back up) so it's tough to say whether the fatigue is from rads, everything else, or everything altogether.

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2013 03:34AM CassDugan wrote: Lenn13ka, I'm happy to "meet" another DF person! Is it patient? Alum? The rads waiting room is so friendly. I'm often tempted to ask if anyone else is active on BCO. CanNOT sleep tonight. My plan is 22 whole breast treatments and 8 cone downs. Treatment later today will be 25/30. My skin still looks good, if very pink. This week was the first time the skin even looked dry. I've been careful to apply aloe 3-4 times a day, perhaps that's helped. At the very least, it helps psychologically. Throughout, my breast has felt warm to the touch which I understand is normal. This is the first week that it has felt warm of itself - kind of like a sunburn. I don't know if it's entirely psychosomatic or what, but since the cone downs started, I've been getting a burning sensation along the incision. That is what's keeping me awake tonight. If either the ibu or the oxycodone are helping with that particular pain, I don't want to think about what it would be like without.

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2013 10:08PM CassDugan wrote: Peg, yes, the x-rays are common. I had tattoos (5 teeny dots) to help align me for treatment. When I began the cone down (I had 22 whole breast + 8 cone downs), the corners of the cone down field were marked with magic marker. Would y'all believe that one of the corners is *still* clearly marked with that ink more than a month later?! Congrats to all the halfway ladies!
Posts.Title: Summer 2013 Rads Wildlyshel sandiesau

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2013 08:47PM CassDugan wrote: 8 of 30 for me today. Had a bit of a stressor last night. A friend who is very knowledgable regarding personal care products recommended a particular aloe product as the only one she would use. I've been using Shea butter on each of the two scars and aloe gel on the remainder of the treatment field twice daily: once when I get home from rads and then again later at night after a shower. I've got the ro's blessing on the Shea butter, the original aloe gel, and the new one my friend recommended. Anyhoo, I used the new gel for the first time last night. Within 30 minutes it was easy to see where it had been applied because the skin was very red, like a sunburn. Needless to say, I jumped right back in the shower and washed it off. I couldn't get back to sleep for being nervous that it might've damaged my skin. It didn't hurt or itch or anything. Luckily, the skin was back to its usual state in about two hours. Maybe the original aloe gel isn't as good but I figure it's better to avoid using something that irritates my skin such that it turns red.

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2013 11:15AM CassDugan wrote: Today marks two weeks past my last treatment. My skin never even started to flake until the last week or so. I now have a line of skin that is tight, shiny, and smooth across my PM scar that is beginning to crack. I expect it will peel soon. The sunburned appearance is rapidly fading. Still using Aloe Life Skin Gel 3x daily and Shea butter across the scars after showering. I start school again next week, which means that not only will I have to wear real clothes, I'll have to wear a top at all! We live in a rural location so I've been mainly going topless all summer. I can't tolerate a bra yet but am a bit self-conscious about going braless in public (b cup). I've gotten some scarves to help disguise things. Any other tips? Also, I could've sworn someone started a post-rads thread for us summer alums. Anyone know where that is?
Posts.Title: Summer 2013 Rads Wildlyshel sandiesau

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2013 08:29PM CassDugan wrote: Oh, absolutely rads impacts the healing process. The rads target everything in their path, not just cancer cells. As I understand it, and perhaps sciencegal can clarify, cancer cells have a shorter cell cycle (I.e. grow and divide at a more rapid pace than healthy somatic cells) and therefore the rads affect the cancer cells to a greater extent. That said, for me, the benefits (lowered recurrence rate) far outweighs the costs (slowed healing). My post surgical inflammation had gone down but is now back, if not as much. My RO says this is normal. My guess is that it's an inflammation response as the tissues try to repair the daily onslaught of rads. I think that's why the general achiness - much like PMS swelling used to be. I've no idea why the shooting pains or why the numbness has returned. Oh yah - the lump feeling in my throat. Turns out the Prilosec was helping, at least somewhat. I stopped taking it and it returned with a vengeance and abated when I restarted taking it. I also find DGL (deglyc... Licorice) very helpful, more than simethicone or mylanta.
